risks.Risk Description: Cybersecurity is identified as a ubiquitous concern, with 78% of respondents rating it as a high or very high risk in their organizations.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Technology drives this risk area, as it is cited as a common driver for the top three highest risks.

risks.Trend: Cybersecurity risk levels have remained consistently high, with audit plans maintaining an elevated allocation compared to 2019 levels.
Contextual Variations: Publicly traded organizations tend to rate cybersecurity risk slightly lower than some other sectors.

risks.Risk Description: IT risk (not covered in other choices) is identified as one of the top three highest risk areas.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Technology drives IT risk, underscoring vulnerabilities linked to digital systems and services.

Contextual Variations: Publicly traded organizations tend to rate IT risk lower than some other sectors.

risks.Risk Description: Third-party relationships are identified as the third highest risk area, with a notable gap—33 percentage points—between perceived high risk and audit frequency.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Reliance on third parties for IT services contributes to this risk.

risks.Risk Description: This risk area evaluates non-ICFR compliance and regulatory risks; specific details are not further elaborated in the report.
Operational risk relates to risks arising from day-to-day organizational operations and is included as one of the risk areas surveyed.
This risk area covers enterprise risk management and its related processes, as identified in the survey responses.
Fraud is highlighted as a key risk area, with nearly 90% of respondents integrating fraud considerations into audits and about half of CAEs responsible for fraud investigations.
This risk addresses issues related to governance and organizational culture, with a reported gap of 20 percentage points between perceived risk and audit frequency.
Risk associated with financial reporting, including internal controls over financial reporting (ICFR), varies significantly with SOX implementation, affecting audit plan allocations.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: The implementation status of Sarbanes-Oxley (SOX) significantly influences the risk profile and audit allocation for financial reporting.

Contextual Variations: Risk levels vary by SOX implementation and organization type, with publicly traded organizations showing different allocations compared to privately held ones.

risks.Risk Description: Cost/expense reduction is regarded as a significant risk area, particularly for nonprofit organizations where the risk level is notably higher.
risks.Trend: Audit allocation for cost/expense reduction has increased since 2019, indicating a growing focus on this risk area.
Contextual Variations: Nonprofit organizations report a higher perception of risk in this area compared to other sectors.

risks.Risk Description: This risk area addresses financial risks not covered under ICFR, though the report provides minimal additional detail.
Risk related to sustainability and nonfinancial reporting is seen as moderate to high by a majority of respondents, especially within publicly traded organizations.
risks.Trend: Audit allocation for sustainability/nonfinancial reporting has increased by over 2 percentage points since 2019.
Contextual Variations: Publicly traded organizations report this risk as moderate to high.
Public sector respondents also express notable concern for this risk area.

risks.Risk Description: This risk area reflects issues associated with supporting external audits, characterized by an audit frequency that is 45 percentage points higher than the perceived risk level.
